speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: She says that CNN's names were on Jeffrey Epstein's private flight log.
date: stated on July 26, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, CNN anchor names weren't on Epstein's flight records.
text: After federal prosecutors filed charges of sexual trafficking of children against rich financier Jeffrey Epstein in early July, stories about those in his high-powered social circle took a new life. But some took advantage of this occasion to spread false rumours about public figures, including putting them on a special Boeing 727 in Epstein. Through the story of a woman who spoke to the Miami Herald newspaper, who filed a civil suit against Epstein, which was settled in 2017, the jet transported young women to entertain guests and named "The Lollita Express," which she described as "the vessel in which girls are abused and go unpunished." One of the problematic Facebook bulletins shares the picture of Photoshop of CNN Chris Como, Brian Stelter and Jake Taber, and claims that the names of the three men are on the flight logs of Lollita Express. The article says, "Hi, CNN... why three of your anchor names on Epstein's flight logs? It was published on the Q Army page, one of several social media pages relevant to the theory of the Q'Anon conspiracy. The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) On January 12, 2021, he wrote in an Instagram article saying that Joe Biden remained silent about the violence in Black Lives-Mite protests. By Tom Kircher • January 16, 2012, this rumor is fabricated. None of their names or initials are on the flight records issued by Epstein. The CNN spokesman Barbara Levin told Bollift Fuckett that there was the truth to Zero about these rumors. The flight records, which were made public through civil actions by women who said that they had been sexually abused by Epstein, extend from 1997 to 2005, and were written by the pilot David Rodgers. Records can be found on the Internet in a few places, and while there are certainly some noteworthy names, such as President Bill Clinton (who issued a statement on flights shortly after Epstein was arrested), CNN's broadcasters' names are not there. Further false lists of alleged passengers of Lulita Express can be found on the Internet, including President Barack Obama, former Vice-President Joe Biden, former United States Senator Hillary Clinton, the late John McCain, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and even Pope Francis, to name but a few. We're assessing this allegation pants on fire!
